prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person in the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about a parent taking their 3-year-old out for a fun activity while the partner is at work.

First, I need to understand the key points. The parent (author) wants to take the child out to places like a play center or a farm. The partner consistently refuses, giving various excuses about not wanting to go, being tired, or not wanting to spend money, even though they can afford it. The author then decides to go with a friend to a petting zoo when the partner is working, and the partner gets upset about it, wanting to cancel and go another day.

The author argues that the partner has refused previously for non-serious reasons. The partner is now upset because they can't go. The question is whether the author is in the wrong.

I should consider common parenting situations. It's common for parents to take turns caring for children and managing their time. If one parent is working, the other might take the child out. The partner's repeated refusals without valid reasons might indicate a pattern of not contributing to childcare or being unwilling to engage. The author is stepping in to provide an activity the child would enjoy, which is reasonable.

The partner's reaction seems to stem from feeling excluded or not being considered. However, the author has already tried suggesting outings that the partner refused. The author isn't going on a movie date alone, just taking the child to a petting zoo. The cost is minimal (£7), and the partner's previous excuses were about money and tiredness despite being able to afford it.

In terms of fairness, the author is fulfilling the child's needs despite the partner's reluctance. The partner might feel left out, but the author isn't doing anything harmful. The key is that the author is acting in the child's best interest, not excluding the partner for selfish reasons. The partner's desire to go another day is a valid request, but the author is also within their rights to make arrangements when the partner isn't available or unwilling.

So, the answer would likely be B (No), because the author isn't in the wrong here. They're making plans when the partner has previously refused and isn't at work, which is a reasonable approach to ensuring the child has fun and social activities.
